newscast.title: The truth on forest fires with Smokey the Bear

actor.name: HOST
actor.passage: Hello, I’m ________________, and welcome to this special edition of Science Buzz 60 Minutes. Tonight we have an unprecedented interview with Smokey the Bear, who’s ready to come clean with the truth on forest fires.

actor.name: SMOKEY
actor.passage: Thank you for having me on the program tonight, ____________. There are a few things I want to get off my chest. In the past I might have been over-reacting a bit about all the dangers of forest fires.

actor.name: HOST
actor.passage: What do you mean, Smokey? Aren’t forest fires always bad?

actor.name: SMOKEY
actor.passage: Let me be clear about this; we still need to be responsible campers and hikers when we’re outdoors. We don’t want to carelessly start forest fires. They can have a devastating impact on forests and people’s property.

actor.name: SMOKEY
actor.passage: People need to know that forest fires that occur naturally are a part of the re-growth cycle.

actor.name: HOST
actor.passage: You’re saying that forests need fires?

actor.name: SMOKEY
actor.passage: When a lightning strike starts a fire in the woods, the ensuing flames and heat burst the cones of pine-type trees and release millions of seeds onto the forest ground. That’s how old trees are naturally culled and new trees begin to grow. Within 30 or 40 years, some of those seeds have grown back into full-size trees.

actor.name: HOST
actor.passage: Anything else you want to tell us about forest fires, Smokey?

actor.name: SMOKEY
actor.passage: Yes, this process should happen around every 100 years to get new trees to grow. But remember, be careful with your campfires, kids.

actor.name: HOST
actor.passage: Thanks for that great information Smokey. This is _________, signing off from Science Buzz 60 Minutes. Be sure to watch our show next week when Woody Woodpecker confesses to the damage his species causes trees.
